Graphical abstract This review provides a comprehensive overview of classification, design and construction of BP-based heterostructures with PEC water splitting and diverse photocatalytic applications, including water splitting, CO2 reduction, N 2 fixation, pollutant degradation, photothermal and photodynamic therapy. Semiconductor-based photocatalytic and photoelectrochemical (PEC) processes can convert solar energy into high-density chemical energy or for the treatment of environmental pollutants, which are ideal ways to deal with environmental and energy crises. The development of high-efficiency photocatalysts and photoelectrodes is the key to the in-depth development and practical application of the two technologies. Black phosphorus (BP) has excellent physicalcochemical properties such as adjustable band gap, high carrier mobility, large specific surface area and anisotropy, making it one of the most promising catalysts. BP-based heterostructure can not only realize the effective separation of photogenerated carriers but also improve the stability of BP, and is widely used in photocatalytic and PEC reactions. In this review, we first introduce the crystal structure, band structure, anisotropy, and preparation of BP with different dimensions (bulk, zero-dimension and two-dimension). Then, according to the transfer path of the photogenerated carriers and the components, the BP-based heterostructures are divided into type I heterojunction, type II heterojunction, Z-scheme heterojunction, S-scheme heterojunction, BP/carbon-based material heterostructure, BP/metal heterostructure and multi-component heterostructure. Highlighted are the diverse photocatalytic applications of BP-based heterostructure, such as water splitting and CO2 reduction, N2 fixation, pollutant degradation, photothermal and photodynamic therapy. Finally, some concluding views and opinions are stated on the challenges and opportunities faced by the further development of BP-based heterostructures in photocatalysis and PEC water splitting. Keywords Black phosphorus Heterostructure Photocatalysis Photoelectrochemical water splitting 1 Introduction The global industrialization process is accompanied by the continuous consumption of fossil energy, which has also exacerbated the energy crisis, climate change and environmental pollution. Using sunlight as an inexhaustible resource to obtain clean energy or to achieve environmental purification or the conversion of greenhouse gases, etc., is the best choice to deal with these problems. Semiconductor-based photocatalysis and photoelectrochemical (PEC) water splitting provides a green and environmentally friendly route to future energy acquisition [1–6]. In particular, photocatalytic technology has been applied for various catalytic directions such as H2 production [7–9], CO2 reduction [10–12], N2 fixation [13], pollutant degradation [14,15], sterilization and disinfection [16] due to its flexible, sustainable, and low-cost characteristics. Since 1972, Fujishima and Honda first discovered that TiO2 as a photoanode can split water into hydrogen and oxygen molecules under ultraviolet irradiation [17], which opened the prelude of PEC water splitting and photocatalysis. Although PEC water splitting and photocatalysis have gone through nearly 50 years of development, the exploration of high-efficiency photocatalysts or photoelectrodes is still a challenge for the development of these two technologies. As a rising star among two-dimensional (2D) materials, black phosphorus (BP) has been applied to field effect transistors (FET) for the first time in 2014 [18], and it is now widely used in various fields, such as catalysis [19–21], energy storage [22,23], photodetectors [24,25], solar cells [26–28], sensors [29,30] and biomedical field [31–33]. BP has a graphite-like layered structure, and the layers are stacked by weak van der Waals forces [34], which makes the bulk BP easily peeled into few layers BP (phosphorene) through the top-down method. It is worth noting that almost all applications of BP are based on BP nanosheets or BP quantum dots, so the exfoliation of bulk BP is of great significance to its application. BP has a direct band gap that can be adjusted from 0.3 eV for bulk BP to 2.0 eV for monolayer BP [35]. The adjustable band gap allows BP to show a wide range of light absorption from ultraviolet to visible and even infrared region, which is a characteristic of ideal photocatalytic and photoelectrochemical materials. In addition, BP also has high carrier mobility, high thermal stability, large switching ratio, large specific surface area and good biocompatibility, making BP an excellent photocatalyst candidate [36,37]. However, due to the defects caused in the preparation process of thin-layer of BP, it is difficult to achieve the ideal carrier mobility, so there is also serious photogenerated carrier recombination [38–43]. Unfortunately, BP, especially thin-layer BP, is extremely sensitive to light, water and oxygen, so its chemical stability is poor [44,45]. The faster recombination of photogenerated carriers and the inherent instability of BP limit its applications in the fields of photocatalysis and PEC water splitting. Therefore, inhibiting the recombination of the photogenerated electrons and holes of the thin-layer BP and improving its stability are the keys to the deep applications of BP in these two catalytic directions. Constructing a heterostructure can promote the effective separation of carriers of catalysts or photoelectrodes, and is an effective means to enhance the performance of the photocatalysts or photoelectrodes [46–48]. At the same time, building a heterostructure with firm chemical bonding between the two materials can also improve the stability of the catalyst. For example, several researches have reported that the P-C bond or P-N bond between BP/g-C3N4 not only effectively transferred the photogenerated carriers, but also enhanced the stability of BP [49–52]. In addition to g-C3N4, some other semiconductors [53–55], noble metals [56–58] and graphene [59,60] were combined with BP to achieve enhanced and stable performance in different photocatalytic reactions. In the aspect of PEC water splitting, there are also important research reports on the combination of BP and traditional photoanodes such as TiO2 and BiVO4 to enhance the PEC performance [61–64]. Although quite a lot of researches have been reported on BP-based heterostructures for photocatalysis and PEC water splitting, there are few related reviews to summarize the classification of BP-based heterostructures and their applications in these two directions. In this review, we provide a comprehensive summary of BP-based heterostructure photocatalysts. The crystal structure, band structure, anisotropy and preparation of BP are introduced firstly. The BP-based heterostructures is divided into type I heterojunctions, type II heterojunctions, Z-scheme heterojunctions, S-scheme heterojunctions, BP/carbon-based material heterostructures, BP/metal heterostructures and multi-component heterostructures according to the mechanism of photogenerated charge separation, and their latest developments of BP-based heterostructures in photocatalytic water splitting, CO2 reduction, N2 fixation, pollutant degradation, photothermal and photodynamic therapy have been summarized. Meanwhile, we also discussed the progress of BP-based photoelectrode materials (mainly with TiO2 and BiVO4) on the PEC water splitting. Finally, the challenges and expectations for the design of BP-based heterostructure photocatalysts and photoelectrodes are put forward. 2 Crystal and band structure of BP 2.1 Crystal structure BP has three crystal structures, namely orthorhombic, hexagonal and cubic phases. It has an orthorhombic structure under normal temperature and pressure, while it will undergo a phase change under high pressure and be converted into a hexagonal structure and a simple cubic structure at 5 GPa and 10 GPa, respectively [36]. As shown in Fig. 1 (a), the bulk BP is composed of monolayer BP combined by van der Waals forces [66], and the layer spacing is about 5.3 Å. Each phosphorus atom is connected to three adjacent phosphorus atoms by covalent bonds and due to the sp3 orbital hybridization between the phosphorus atoms, the monolayer BP is in the shape of a wrinkled honeycomb. This wrinkled structure also gives BP two different bond angles of 96.300° (Fig. 1b) and 102.095° (Fig. 1c), both of which are close to the angle of a perfect tetragonal structure (109.5°). The monolayer BP contains two atomic layers, in which the bond length between adjacent phosphorus atoms in the same plane is 2.224 Å, and the bond length between top and bottom phosphorus atoms is 2.244 Å (Fig. 1b). The x and y axis directions of the BP structure (Fig. 1a and c) correspond to the armchair direction and zigzag direction, respectively. Along the two directions, BP exhibits unique electronic, optical, and thermal anisotropy, which allow it a broader application prospect than other 2D materials. 2.2 Band structure of BP The band structure of semiconductors is of great significance to their photocatalytic applications, and the adjustable bandgap structure allows BP great advantages in its photocatalytic application. The determination of the band gap and energy level position of BP is very important for the rational design of BP-based photocatalysts or photoelectrodes and the exploration of its reaction mechanism. In 1953, Keyes first experimentally measured the band gap of bulk BP to be 0.33 eV [70]. In the following sixty years, due to the difficulty of preparing bulk BP and the lack of advanced characterization methods, the research on the energy band structure of BP is stagnant. Until 2014, Tran et al theoretically calculated the band gap of bulk BP to be 0.3 eV [35], which was close to the experimental results of Keyes. Taking this as a starting point, theoretical calculations and experiments have explored the evolution of the band gap from bulk BP to few-layer BP [67–69,71–73], but it is still difficult to give precise values. Rudenko et al. calculated by the GW approximation that the band gap of bulk BP was about 0.1 eV [67]. Although this value was relatively small, it was expected to be improved by the self-consistent of G and W. On this basis, they further calculated the band gap of 1–4 layers of phosphorene, as shown in the Fig. 2 (a). In addition, they described the orbital composition of the energy band by projecting the GW quasiparticle states onto the canonical s and pi (i = x, y, z) orbitals. The conduction band (CB) and the valence band (VB) were formed by a mixture of s and pi orbitals, but py was not involved. Compared with the band structure of graphite whose band structure was determined only by the pz state, the band structure of BP was more concise because of the asymmetry of the mixed state. Experimentally, PL and absorption spectra were used to determine the band gap of BP. Zhang et al. determined the band gaps of 2, 3, 4, and 5 layers of BP by PL spectra to be 1.29, 0.98, 0.88, and 0.80 eV (Fig. 2b), respectively, which matched their theoretical calculation results (Fig. 2c) [68]. Compared with the PL spectra measurements, the absorption spectrum is more tolerant of defects and impurities, which makes it more accurate to determine the band gap of thin-layer and bulk BP. In the research work of Li et al., they used absorption spectra to determine the band gaps of single-layer, double-layers, triple-layers and bulk BP to be 1.73, 1.15, 0.83 and 0.35 eV, respectively (Fig. 2d) [68]. Theoretical calculations and experimental results displayed that the band gap of bulk BP and monolayer BP was 0.1–0.36 eV and 1–2.29 eV, respectively, and the band gap tended to increase as the thickness becomes thinner. In addition, the band gap of BP can also be adjusted by external adjustment methods such as doping [74], applying an external electric field [75], and strain engineering [76]. 3 Anisotropy of BP The anisotropy of a material means that its physical properties show different changes along different crystal orientations. The in-plane anisotropy of BP is caused by its different bond lengths and bond angles along the orthogonal plane [77,78]. The structural anisotropy of BP enables it to exhibit in-plane anisotropy in optical, electrical, thermal, mechanical, and vibration along the armchair and zigzag directions [79]. Many novel optoelectronic devices can be designed using the characteristics of anisotropy. Here, we focus on the anisotropy of BP in optic, electrical and thermal properties. 3.1 Optical anisotropy The optical anisotropy makes the thin-layer BP have linear dichroism, which can be observed by polarization-dependent light absorption [83,84], transmission [83], and reflection [69,85]. Chen et al. characterized the BP with a thickness of about 30 nm by infrared spectroscopy, and the results showed that the polarized light along the armchair direction in the infrared range showed a stronger extinction effect (Fig. 3 a). Qiao et al. calculated the light absorption spectra of few-layer phosphorene and bulk BP through the dielectric function under different polarized light [71]. As shown in the Fig. 3(b and c), although with the increase of the number of dielectric polarization layers, the edge of the energy absorption in the armchair and zigzag directions gradually decreased, but it was obvious that the armchair direction dropped faster, and the absorption energy edge of zigzag polarized light had higher energy, suggesting that the armchair direction was more conducive to the absorption of polarized light. The research work of Ling et al. showed that BP with thicknesses of 9 and 225 nm exhibited enhanced light absorption for incident light polarized along the armchair direction [84]. The results of these theoretical calculations and experiments indicate that the light absorption of BP was related to crystallographic orientation. Zhang et al. further calculated the light absorption coefficient in the armchair direction was ten times that in the zigzag direction [86]. At the same time, the diffusion of photons in the armchair direction was 16 times larger than that in the zigzag direction, which was of great significance to the photocatalytic process that relies on photogenerated carriers. 3.2 Electrical anisotropy Apart from optical anisotropy, the electrical anisotropy of BP is also outstanding. The different effective masses of electrons and holes along the armrest direction and the zigzag direction result in the high electrical anisotropy of BP. In 1983, Zhang et al. measured the carrier mobility and electrical conductivity of bulk BP through the multi-faceted Hall effect [77], and the results showed that BP had the highest carrier mobility along the armchair direction compared to the zigzag and the in-plane direction (Fig. 3d). In the subsequent work, the conductivity and carrier mobility in the armchair direction were demonstrated to be higher than that in the zigzag direction in few-layer BP (Fig. 3e and f) [80]. In addition, Zhao et al. also predicted theoretically that the electron mobility along the armchair direction (1100–1140 cm2 v-1s−1) in the single-layer phosphorene was 14 times that of in the zigzag direction (80 cm2 V−1 s−1), while the hole mobility along the zigzag direction was between 10,000 and 26000 cm2 V−1 s−1, which was 40 times that along the armchair direction (640–700 cm2 V−1 s−1) [71]. The excellent charge mobility of BP is of great significance to the transfer of electrons and holes. In short, both theoretical and experimental results prove the electronic anisotropy of BP. 3.3 Thermal anisotropy In 1974, Hu et al. detected that the bulk BP has a larger coefficient of thermal expansion along the direction of the armchair, which proved the thermal anisotropy of BP [87]. For the first time, Fei et al. used first-principles calculations to theoretically predict the in-plane thermoelectric transmission behavior of monolayer BP [81]. Unlike the electrical conductivity mainly along the armchair direction, the in-plane thermal conductivity of the BP in the zigzag direction was significantly stronger than that in the armchair direction (Fig. 3g). Jain et al. predicted that the thermal conductivity of BP in the zigzag direction at room temperature is about 110 Wm-1K−1, while the thermal conductivity in the armchair direction is about 36 Wm-1K−1 [88], which was consistent with the results reported by Fei et al. Luo et al. measured the in-plane thermal conductivity of few-layer BP with a thickness between 9–30 nm using micro-Raman technology (Fig. 3h) [82]. The experimental results showed that the thermal conductivity of the thin-layer BP nanosheets varies from 10 to 20 Wm-1K−1 along the armchair direction and from 20 to 40 Wm-1K−1 along the zigzag direction (Fig. 3i), and exhibited thickness-dependent anisotropic changes in thermal conductivity. Zhang et al. also observed the anisotropy and thickness dependence of thermal conductivity in BP with thicknesses of 170, 270 and 310 nm [89]. In terms of thickness dependence, both research results indicate that the thinner BP had lower thermal conductivity, which was caused by the scattering of crystals in the thin-layer of BP lattice. The interaction of BP's thermal conductivity and electrical conductivity anisotropy makes it potentially useful in thermoelectrics. 4 Preparation of BP 4.1 Synthesis of bulk BP The synthesis of BP has a history of more than one hundred years, and several synthetic methods have been developed, such as high temperature and high pressure method, mercury catalysis method, liquid bismuth recrystallization method, and chemical vapor transport method. 4.1.1 High temperature and high pressure method In 1914, Bridgman firstly converted white phosphorus (WP) into BP within 5–30 minutes under a hydrostatic pressure of 1.2 GPa and a temperature of 200 °C [94]. The density of the prepared bulk BP is as high as 2.69 kg/cm3, which is 15% higher than the maximum density of red phosphorus (RP). Compared with RP and WP, pure BP is absolutely stable in the air and will not ignite spontaneously even when it is heated to 400 °C. At the same time, it will neither significantly interact with sulfuric acid nor be dissolved by CS2, showing good chemical stability. Later, some researchers also used high temperature and high pressure conversion method to prepare BP [95,96]. Shoichi used RP as a raw material to prepare bulk BP under isostatic condition (∼1 Gpa) [95]. The system was first heated to about 550 °C to generate polycrystalline BP, then melted at 900 °C, and finally cooled slowly to solidify into single crystal BP with a crystal size of larger than 5 × 5 × 10 mm3. Nevertheless, all of these preparation methods require relatively strict experimental conditions and complex experimental equipment, which are difficult for most laboratories to achieve. 4.1.2 Mercury catalysis and liquid bismuth recrystallization method After the 1950 s, mercury catalytic method and liquid bismuth recrystallization method were used to prepare BP crystals. Krebs employed mercury to catalyze WP under low pressure and high temperature conditions to convert it into BP [97]. However, the prepared BP crystal contained 25wt%-30wt% of mercury, some of which would leak out of the material after a period of time, causing the material to be contaminated. In 1965, Brown et al. found that BP with good crystallinity can be obtained in liquid bismuth [78]. The WP purified by nitric acid was dissolved in a liquid bismuth bath and heated to 400 °C in a vacuum quartz glass tube to obtain BP crystal. In 1989, needle-shaped and film shaped BP crystals were prepared by the improved bismuth-flux method [98]. In this method, RP was used as the starting material, which was converted into white phosphorus under vacuum conditions, and then BP single crystals were grown in the solution of white phosphorus in liquid bismuth. But the toxicity of bismuth makes the preparation of BP full of hidden dangers. In addition, the lower BP yield is even less satisfying. Taking into account the above shortcomings, these two methods have been seldom used in these years. 4.1.3 Chemical vapor transport method In 2007, Lange et al. synthesized high-quality BP single crystals for the first time by chemical vapor transport (CVT) [99]. This method was based on the concept of mineralization, that was, Au, Sn, SnI4 and other mineralizers were used in the reaction process. During the reaction, various mineralizers and RP as raw material were vacuum-sealed in a quartz tube, slowly heated to about 600 °C, maintained at this temperature for 5–10 days, and then slowly dropped to room temperature for obtaining the final bulk BP. Subsequently, Nilges et al. replaced Sn and Au in the mineralizer with SnAu, and prepared BP crystals of larger size (greater than 1 cm) in 2008 [100]. Six years later, Köpf et.al has made greater improvements in the selection of mineralizers [90]. Only Sn and SnI4 were used as mineralizers, eliminating the precious metal gold in the preparation process. This improvement can still obtain high-quality, large-yield, and orthorhombic BP with a size larger than a few millimeters while reducing costs (Fig. 4 a). In 2016, Wang and his collaborators conducted a more in-depth study on the preparation of bulk BP and its growth mechanism [91,101]. In their research work, I2 was selected as mineralizer to replace the original SnI4. The improvement on the BP synthesis process is mainly reflected in two aspects: one is to replace the expensive SnI4 with cheap I2, which greatly reduces the cost of raw materials; on the other hand, they prepare BP for the first time in an argon atmosphere, so that the BP preparation process is more streamlined [101]. In terms of growth mechanism, Wang et al. revealed the role of specific metals (or alloys) and I2 in the growth process through experiments [91]. It was found that I2 can dissolve and promote the transport of phosphorus during the growth process, while specific metals (or alloys) provide a liquid solution. Under the synergistic effect of the above two aspects, phosphorus is effectively dissolved in a high temperature environment, and then the phosphorus precipitates and crystallizes to form BP crystals during the slow cooling stage. Finally, the conversion efficiency of the prepared BP nanobelt can reach 97% (Fig. 4b). 4.2 Synthesis of few-layer BP (phosphorene) Compared with the corresponding bulk materials, the atomic-thick 2D materials have unique physicalcochemical properties such as planar conductivity, electronic anisotropy, adjustable band structure and high surface activity. Therefore, the acquisition of few-layer BP is the key to the wide application of BP. Since BP was first applied to field effect transistors in 2014, various methods and techniques for obtaining few-layer BP have sprung up. In view of the environmentally friendly and energy-saving characteristics of photocatalysis and PEC water splitting, a simple, low-cost, and large-scale method of obtaining few-layer BP is needed. At present, many strategies have been developed to obtain few-layer BP, which can be divided into two categories: top-down and bottom-up methods. The top-down methods include mechanical exfoliation [18,102–105], liquid-phase exfoliation [92,106–113], electrochemical exfoliation [93,114–116], alkali metal intercalation [117], plasma etching [118,119], thermal sublimation [120,121], anodic oxidation [122] and chemical thinning method [123]. The bottom-up approaches include CVD [124], pulsed laser deposition [125–127], solvothermal method [128,129] and lateral growth method [130]. However, in view of the existence form, quality and quantity of few-layer BP obtained by these methods, the few-layer BP materials acquired by mechanical exfoliation, liquid-phase exfoliation and electrochemical exfoliation are more widely used in photocatalysis or PEC water splitting. Here the above three methods are briefly introduced. 4.2.1 Mechanical exfoliation The top-down peeling method is suitable for 2D materials that are formed by weak van der Waals forces, such as graphene, transition metal chalcogenides, BP, etc. According to multi-level quantum chemistry calculations, the energy required for the peeling of BP per atom is 151 meV [131], which provides a theoretical basis for the external force to peel off the BP. In 2014, the sticky-tape microcleavage method was used for the first time to obtain few-layer or single-layer phosphorene [102]. Although high-quality phosphorene can be obtained by this method, the yield is small and the thickness and size of phosphorene are not controllable, so it is difficult to be used for photocatalysis or PEC water splitting. Ball milling can also be used as a mechanical exfoliation method for the preparation of few-layer BP. Zhang et al. used LiOH as an additive to obtain BP nanosheets by ball-milling bulk BP [105]. The BP nanosheets obtained by ball milling have a lateral size of 30–60 nm and a thickness of 0.8–6 nm, which show excellent performance for photocatalytic hydrogen production. As an additive, LiOH can inhibit the phase change from BP to RP during the ball milling process, and on the other hand it can bond hydroxyl groups on the edges of the BP nanosheets to stabilize the photocatalytic performance of the BP nanosheets. In addition, it is reported that the BP nanosheets and C60 composites were prepared by ball milling method for photocatalytic reaction [132]. Although the ball milling method can produce BP nanosheets, the instability and low yield in the ball milling process make this method not widely used for photocatalytic applications. 4.2.2 Liquid-phase exfoliation Liquid-phase exfoliation is also a classic top-down method for preparing 2D materials, and has been widely used in the exfoliation of transition metal chalcogenide compounds, hexagonal boron nitride and graphene. The liquid-phase exfoliation process is to disperse the bulk material in an organic solvent that matches its surface energy, and peel off the nanosheets from the bulk material under the assistance of ultrasound. Liquid-phase exfoliation has been proven to be an effective way to obtain large-scale 2D materials, and the size and concentration of the 2D flakes can also be controlled by stripping time and separation procedures. Therefore, the selection of a suitable organic solvent is the key to effectively stripping and obtaining high-quality few-layer BP. Zhang et al. used NMP to exfoliate the BP for the first time and obtained 1–5 layers of phosphorene [111]. Zhang et al. used a variety of solvents such as hexane, IPA, methanol, ethanol, acetone, THF, chloroform, NMF, DCB, CHP, NVP, DMSO, formamide, etc. to perform liquid phase exfoliation of BP [109], as shown in the Fig. 4(c). The concentration of BP nanosheets obtained by stripping was in descending order of formamide > DMSO > DMF-NMP-IPA > ethanol-methanol > acetone-THF-deionized water. The BP nanosheets are obtained with a higher yield and more stable in aqueous solution by stripping in alkaline NMP. Although there are so many advantages to stripping BP in organic solvents, the BP nanosheets obtained in organic solvents is difficult to directly apply to photonics or electronic applications due to the residue of organic solvents. In view of this, Liu et al. used PDDA passivation to peel off bulk BP in an aqueous solution to obtain BP nanosheets with high stability and high dispersion, which were successfully used as a saturable absorber in fiber lasers [92]. The positively charged N atom of PDDA combines with the lone pair of electrons on the P 3 s orbital through electrostatic adsorption, which stabilizes the lone pair of electrons (Fig. 4d). In addition, the alkyl group of PDDA can act as a physical isolation layer to further prevent BP from contacting O2 and H2O. Liquid-phase exfoliation provides the basis for many applications of BP, especially photocatalytic fields. Many photocatalytic researches based on the thin-layer of BP are obtained by liquid-phase exfoliation. 4.2.3 Electrochemical exfoliation The electrochemical exfoliation method is to apply a voltage to the ionic liquid (electrolyte) to cause structure expansion of the samples, thereby achieving the acquisition of thin-layer samples. The commonly used electrochemical exfoliation methods such as cation and anion intercalation have been successfully applied to transition metal chalcogenides, graphene and other 2D materials. Huang et al. controlled the thickness of the obtained BP nanosheets by adjusting the bias voltage to intercalate quaternary ammonium cations in BP, and obtained BP nanosheets ranging from 2 to 11 layers [116], which can be directly used as the anode materials of sodium ion batteries. Huang et al. used sulfuric acid as the electrolyte (Fig. 4e), and promoted the wetting of the crystals and the intercalation of electrolyte ions by applying a short-term DC voltage in advance (Fig. 4f) [93]. Then, the BP was peeled off under a voltage of + 3 V for 2 h with the gradual color change of the solution from white to yellow (Fig. 4g), which proved that the thin-layer BP was obtained. Compared with liquid-phase exfoliation that requires long-term ultrasound assistance, electrochemical exfoliation shows obvious advantages, which can produce a large amount of high-quality few-layer BP in a short time. 4.3 Synthesis of BP quantum dots The quantum confinement and edge effects make quantum dots (QDs) have unique applications in the field of electronics and optoelectronics. In 2015, BP QDs with a lateral size of 4–8 nm and a thickness of 3–8 nm were fabricated for the first time by liquid phase exfoliation, which exhibited excellent flash memory effect and stability as a flexible device [133]. Sun et al. successfully obtained ultra-small BP QDs with a lateral size of 2.6 nm and a thickness of about 1.5 nm in the NMP solution by combining probe ultrasound and water bath ultrasound [134]. Furthermore, the combination of BP QDs and PEG displayed a photothermal conversion efficiency of 28.4%, indicating its great potential as a photothermal reagent. Tang et al. prepared fluorinated BPQDs (F-BPQDs) with excellent stability by electrochemical stripping method and synchronous fluorination method [135]. Solvothermal method is also a very effective method for obtaining BP QDs. Bulk BP dispersed in the NMP solution was vigorously stirred for 12 h under a N2 atmosphere at 140 ℃, and finally BP QDs with an average circumference of 1.76 nm and a thickness of about 1.2 nm were acquired [136]. Wang and Xu et al. also successfully prepared BP QDs in a NaOH saturated NMP solution using a similar solvothermal method [137,138]. In addition to the above methods, pulsed laser deposition [139] and blender breaking methods [140] have also been reported to be applied to the preparation of BP QDs. In a word, the method of obtaining BP QDs is mostly the same as that of obtaining 2D BP, and BP in different dimensions can be obtained under different preparation conditions. BP QDs have also been well applied in photocatalysis and PEC water splitting. 5 Techniques for passivating BP BP is unstable and easily decomposed in air, which limits its practical application. From the structural point of view, each phosphorus atom has five valence electrons, of which three valence electrons are distributed in three 3p orbitals and covalently bond with three adjacent phosphorus atoms to form a relatively stable structure, while the lone pair of electrons distributed on one orbital exists independently and easily reacts with oxygen to cause the degradation of BP under ambient conditions [141]. From the perspective of the specific decomposition process, BP is easy to decompose when light, oxygen and water coexist. Luo et al. theoretically predicted the decomposition mechanism of BP that BP generated superoxide under light and further reacted with water to form P x O y [142]. Luo et al. used XPS spectroscopy to explore the kinetic process of BP nanosheets oxidation by adjusting the oxidation environment (different ratios of water and oxygen) [143]. According to experimental observations, they believed that the oxidation of BP originated from the synergistic effect of water molecules and oxygen molecules, in which water molecules reacted with surface oxides to promote the oxidation process. However, some research work showed that BP can exist stably in anaerobic water, and can be used in humidity detectors or combined with other semiconductor materials for photocatalysis [144,145]. The theoretical research results of Wang et al. showed that oxygen would spontaneously dissociate to phosphorene at room temperature, while water molecules would not directly interact with phosphorene [146]. In addition, the decomposition of BP also depended on the thickness of the BP layer. Specifically, the thinner the layer was, the faster the decomposition rate was [142]. Starting from the oxidation mechanism of BP, many methods were adopted to prevent the direct contact of BP with water and oxygen, such as organic functionalization method [147-149], encapsulation method [150-152] and ion modification method [45,153]. 5.1 Organic functionalization method The organic matter is combined with BP in a covalent bond or noncovalent bond, which can prevent the direct contact of BP with water and oxygen, thereby improving the stability of the BP. Anthraquinone (AQ) and BP nanosheets (BPSE) realized non-covalent bonding through van der Waals force contact, which effectively inhibited the decomposition of BPSE and AQ provided additional charge storage for the BPSE [147]. Zhang et al. combined 7,7,8,8-tetracyano-p-quinodimethane and perylene bisimide with BP nanosheets by noncovalent bonding, which also achieved a stable passivation effect [148]. The covalent modification is to directly bond the lone pair electrons of BP with other atoms on the organic matter, so as to avoid the exposure of lone pair electrons and improve the stability of BP. Zhao et al. used titanium sulfonic acid to coordinate with BP on the surface to form P-Ti coordination, which occupied the position of the lone pair of electrons, thereby inhibiting the oxidation and decomposition of BP [149]. It is worth noting that the organic functionalization method not only improves the stability of BP, but also has no negative affect on its excellent performance, and the passivation effect can reach the desired state. 5.2 Encapsulation method Compared with the organic functionalization method, the encapsulation method is a physical passivation method that does not change the characteristics of BP. Pei et al. used O2 plasma etching method to controllably prepare few to monolayer BP and further deposited about 1 nm Al2O3 on the etched phosphorene’s surface by atomic layer deposited (ALD) [150]. The BP nanosheets encapsulated by Al2O3 still maintained a good morphology after one month in the air, while the pure BP nanosheets have almost been completely oxidized and decomposed after 6 h in the air. The BN-BP-BN heterostructure constructed by encapsulating a few pieces of BP between BN showed excellent stability in the atmospheric environment after high temperature annealing [151]. At the same time, the heterostructure had a carrier mobility of about 1350 cm2 V−1 s−1 and a switching ratio of greater than 105. Zhang et al. coated 5 nm thickness BN/Al2O3 hybrid on few layer BP, and no surface changes were observed in the 30 nm BP flakes after being encapsulated after 6 months [152]. 5.3 Metal ion modification method The bonding of metal ions with BP through chemical bonds is another effective way to improve the stability of BP. Guo et al. reported that Ag+ and BP were covalently bonded through cation-Π interaction to passivate BP. Ag+ modified BP nanosheets remained stable in an environment where the air humidity reached 95% and had a significant improvement in electrical properties [45]. In addition, they also studied Mg2+, Fe3+ and Hg2+ modified BP nanosheets, all of which have varying degrees of stability and electronic performance improvements. Wu et al. coordinated the empty orbital of lanthanide ions with the lone pair of electrons of BP, which effectively improved the stability of BP with different dimensions (BP nanosheets or BP QDs) [153]. Due to the inherent fluorescence characteristics and nuclear magnetic resonance contrast of lanthanide ions, it has great application potential in biomedicine. 6 Classification of BP-based heterostructure photocatalysts Due to the existence of the lone pair of electrons, BP is extremely easy to decompose with the coexistence of water and oxygen. Many studies have reported that the chemical bonding between BP and other materials (including semiconductors and metals) in the heterostructure can inhibit the decomposition of BP, thus contributing the formation of a stable photocatalyst. In addition, the construction of BP-based heterostructure has the following benefits: 1) Due to the wide spectral absorption range of BP (ultraviolet–visible-near infrared), the construction of BP-based photocatalysts or photoelectrodes can make full use of the solar spectrum. 2) Efficient separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs can be realize between BP and other photocatalysts or photoelectrodes. 3) BP can be used as a metal-free co-catalyst to improve the kinetics of the surface redox reaction of photocatalysts or photoelectrodes due to its flexible band gap position, large specific surface area, abundant active sites and ability to shuttle carriers quickly [34,154]. According to the previous reports, BP-based heterostructure photocatalysts can be divided into the following categories: BP-based type I heterojunction, BP-based type II heterojunction, BP-based Z-scheme heterojunction, BP-based S-scheme heterojunction, BP/carbon-based material heterostructure, BP/metal heterostructure and BP-based multi-component heterostructure. 6 6.1 BP-based type I heterojunction The type I heterojunction is illustrated in Fig. 5 (a), the CB position of semiconductor A is more negative than semiconductor B, and the VB position of semiconductor A is more negative than semiconductor B. Therefore, the electrons at the CB position of the semiconductor A and the holes at the VB will be transferred and accumulated on the CB and VB of the semiconductor B, respectively. Since electrons and holes are transferred to a narrower-band-gap semiconductor in type I heterojunction, this is unfavorable for the spatial separation of electron-hole pairs and the strong redox ability of electrons and holes. However, the band gap of BP is adjustable and narrow, and it is easy to form a nested type I structure with semiconductors with a wide band gap and relatively negative CB. Carbon nitride (CN) is a photocatalyst with visible light response that has received widespread attention. Generally, the band gap of CN is 2.7 eV, and the positions of the CB and VB are at −1.1 and + 1.6 eV vs NHE, respectively [156]. Such a band structure makes CN easy to form a nested type I structure with BP. Zhu et al. reported for the first time that BP/CN heterojunction photocatalysts were used for photocatalytic H2 production with methanol as a sacrificial reagent [52]. The BP/CN heterojunction exhibited enhanced photocatalytic H2 production performance under both visible light (Fig. 6 a) and near-infrared light (Fig. 6b). Owing to the type I junction between BP and CN, BP receives electrons from CN to achieve effective separation of photogenerated electrons under the irradiation of visible light (Fig. 6c). The P-N covalent bond formed by the interfacial contact between BP and CN captured the electrons to promote H2 production. When irradiated with light greater than 780 nm, the electrons generated by the excitation of BP were captured by the P-N defects at the BP/CN interface, accelerating the generation of H2. The 2D/2D heterostructure is an ideal heterostructure, which can make two semiconductors fully contact and realize the effective separation of photogenerated carriers. The g-C3N4/BP photocatalyst with 2D/2D heterostructure (Fig. 6d) constructed by electrostatic self-assembly method showed excellent photocatalytic hydrogen production performance under illumination with light wavelength greater than 420 nm (Fig. 6e) and 475 nm (Fig. 6f) [155]. Under λ > 420 nm light irradiation, the type I structure between g-C3N4 and BP can effectively promote the separation of carriers (Fig. 6g), thereby enhancing the photocatalytic performance of the composite. While under λ > 475 nm light irradiation, the electrons generated by BP are captured by the interfacial trap states for H2 production since g-C3N4 cannot be excited (Fig. 6h). More importantly, the g-C3N4 protected the BP in the composites from being oxidized and showed stable performance during long-term photocatalytic H2 production. As an organic–inorganic hybrid perovskite, methylammonium lead iodide perovskite (MAPbI3) with high absorption coefficient and a narrow optical band gap can also be used as a candidate for compositing with BP [160,161]. Li et al. combined thin-layer BP with MAPbI3 to form MAPbI3/BP heterojunction in MAPbI3-saturated aqueous HI solution by electrostatic coupling for H2 generated hydrogen by photocatalytic HI splitting (Fig. 7 a) [157]. The type I band configuration allowed the photogenerated electrons and holes from MAPbI3 to migrate to the CB and VB of BP, respectively (Fig. 7b). The holes in the VB of BP participated in the oxidation reaction of I-, and the electrons in the CB of BP reduced the protons to produce H2. RP, an allotrope of BP, is also an excellent photocatalyst, and RP can undergo phase change to be converted into BP through long-time ball milling [162]. Based on the above characteristics of RP, Shen et al. used a simple ball milling method to prepare a BP-RP heterostructure [158]. As a metal-free photocatalyst, the BP-RP showed excellent performance in degradation of Rhodamine B (RhB) (Fig. 7c). Through experiments and theoretical calculations, they determined that BP-RP heterojunction was a type I heterostructure (Fig. 7d), and the high carrier mobility of BP promoted the migration of photogenerated carriers in the heterojunction, thereby realizing the high visible light catalytic activity of the heterojunction photocatalyst. Covalent triazine framework (CTF) is applied to photocatalysis and PEC water splitting because of its simple preparation, suitable energy band structure and high physical and chemical stability [163,164]. At the same time, the limited visible light absorption range and serious bulk carrier recombination also limit its photocatalytic performance [165,166]. The ultra-thin metal-free 2D/2D BP/CTF (Fig. 7e) photocatalyst was constructed by the ultrasonic-assisted liquid-phase exfoliation method, which showed excellent performance in photocatalytic H2 production (Fig. 7f) and pollutant degradation (Fig. 7g) [159]. A possible mechanism for photocatalytic water splitting BP/CTF was proposed as that the energy band structure of type I encouraged the separation of photogenerated carriers in heterojunction catalysts (Fig. 7h), and further reduced protons to H2 under the action of Pt. Here, the BP-based type I heterojunction materials were summarized in Table 1 . In type I heterojunction, the effective carrier separation can be realized, and the broad photoabsorption range of BP, effective interface contact and chemical bonding synergistically promote the photocatalytic performance of the heterojunction photocatalysts. However, it is worth noting that the charge carriers in the type I heterojunction will all flow to the semiconductor with a narrower band gap, it makes the separation of photogenerated carriers insufficient, which often needs to add a noble metal cocatalysts to improve this defect. In addition, the semiconductor with a narrower bad gap has a weaker redox ability, and it is difficult to achieve effective photocatalytic water splitting without the addition of sacrificial reagents. 6.2 BP-based type II heterojunction The type II heterojunction has a staggered band structure, as shown in the Fig. 5(b). The photogenerated electrons and holes will be concentrated on a relatively positive CB in one semiconductor and a relatively negative VB in another semiconductor under light excitation, realizing effective spatial separation of electrons and holes. Ran et al. theoretically calculated that compared with the bulk BP, the few-layer phosphene (FPS) had a suitable energy band structure, more active sites, and stronger electronic coupling with other semiconductors, so it can serve as a metal-free co-catalyst of photocatalysts [154]. Based on the results of theoretical calculations, they used FPS as a metal-free co-catalysts to combine with CdS (CS), Zn0.8Cd0.2S (ZCS) and ZnS (ZS) for photocatalytic H2 production. Among them, the visible light H2 production efficiency and the apparent quantum efficiency at 420 nm of 1wt% FPS modified CdS (1wt% FPS/CS) reached 11192 µmol h-1g−1 (Fig. 8 a) and 37.2%, respectively. The type II heterojunction of FPS/CS enabled the photogenerated electrons to quickly migrate to FPS, and the FPS as a metal-free co-catalyst further quickly transferred the photogenerated electrons to the active site and reduced the protons adsorbed there into H2 (Fig. 8b). TiO2 is currently one of the most widely used photocatalysts, but the wide band gap also limits its ability to absorb visible light [193,194]. Ossama Elbanna et al. used BP nanosheets (BPNS) to sensitize TiO2 mesocrystals (TMC) (Fig. 8c) to construct photocatalysts with visible-near infrared light response and excellent H2 production performance [175]. They used BPNS of different thicknesses to sensitize TMC, and the results showed that the thinner BPNS sensitized TMC performed the best. The authors proved the migration of photogenerated electrons from BPNS to TMC through time-resolved diffuse reflectance spectral (fs-TRDRS) and determined the type II band gap structure between BP and TiO2 combined their band structures (Fig. 8d). This work paved the way for the combination of BP and metal oxides in photocatalysis and optoelectronic applications. In addition to the 2D BP nanosheets, zero-dimensional (0D) BP quantum dots also have important applications in photocatalysis. Recently, Xu’s research group prepared a BP quantum dots-ZnIn2S4 (BP/ZIS) heterojunction (Fig. 8e) photocatalyst to achieve simultaneous production of syngas and high value-added organics in a redox cycle under visible light [177]. The formation of type II heterostructure between ZnIn2S4 and BP promoted the effective separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs, increased reactive sites, and optimized the adsorption strength of key reaction intermediates for the reduction of CO2. As shown in the Fig. 8(f), the electrons and protons produced by the half-reaction of dehydrogenation could be used for the reduction of CO2, which promoted the production of BDA and mixed gas. This study provided a new idea on the construction of heterojunction photocatalysts for coupling dual-functional photo-redox catalytic systems. Here some typical BP-based type II heterojunction photocatalytic systems were summarized in Table 1. Though efficient charge separation can be achieved in type II heterojunction system by separating the electrons and holes at different semiconductors, the unfavorable band structure make the electrons and holes possess low reduction and oxidation driving force. 6.3 BP-based Z-scheme heterojunction The ideal heterojunction system can not only realize the effective spatial separation of electron-hole pairs but also maintain the high oxidation and reduction potentials of the heterojunction catalyst. The Z-scheme heterojunction can achieve the above expectations because of its charge transfer mechanism similar to plant photosynthesis. As shown in the Fig. 5(c), the electrons from the CB of semiconductor A are transferred to the electron mediator, and then transferred from the electron mediator to the VB of semiconductor B and recombined with the holes there. Owing to the zigzag-like charge transport path, electrons with larger reducing power and holes with higher oxidizing power are preserved, and at the same time more effective spatial separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs is obtained. In this way, the Z-scheme that requires an electron mediator is called an all-solid-state Z-scheme mechanism [195]. However, the electron mediator in the all-solid-state Z-scheme is often some precious metals (gold, silver, platinum), which increases the preparation cost of the catalyst and also limits the light absorption capacity of the photocatalyst itself [196,197]. In the follow-up research, the researchers found that only the two semiconductors with suitable band structure that are in close contact can realize the Z-scheme charge transfer path (Fig. 5d). In this way, the Z-scheme that does not require a transmission medium is called the direct Z-scheme [47,198]. Some typical BP-based Z-scheme heterojunctions are listed in the Table 1. The traditional all-solid-state Z-scheme usually requires noble metal electronic mediators to shuttle electrons, but recent studies have reported that Mxene materials can also be used as solid-state-electron mediators in photocatalysis due to their good metallic properties and rapid photogenerated electron transfer capabilities [199–201]. Zhou et al. prepared a dual-effective CN/MXene/BP Z-scheme heterojunction through a simple solid mixing and calcination method (Fig. 9 a), which showed excellent CIP degradation ability [181]. The lattice spacing of BP, Mxene and CN is observed as shown in Fig. 9(b), indicating the close contact between them. The active species capture experiments (Fig. 9c) and Electron spin resonance (ESR) (Fig. 9d) proved that the main active species in this reaction system were superoxide radicals (•O2 −) and singlet oxygen (1O2). Combining the band structures of CN and BP nanosheets and the results of active species detection, a Z-scheme charge transfer path was proposed (Fig. 9e), that was, mxene acted as an electron mediator to transfer electrons from the CB of CN to the VB of BP. In addition, the P bridging between N atoms and P atoms also accelerated the transfer of photogenerated carriers and promoted the photocatalytic process. The Z-scheme junction and P bridging effect reflect the dual-effective advantanges of this system. Wang et al. developed all solid-state 2D/2D BP/α-Fe2O3 Z-scheme heterostructure (Fig. 9f), in which BP can be used as a H2 evolution catalyst as well as an excellent electron mediator for electron transport [182]. With using Co3O4 and Pt as the H2 and O2 evolution co-catalysts, the H2 and O2 output of the optimal sample was 2.93 and 1.47 umol after 5 h, respectively (Fig. 9g). The characteristic signal of ∙OH was observed from the ESR measurment, which supported the Z-scheme transfer mechanism between BP and α-Fe2O3 (Fig. 9h), so the photogenerated electrons and holes with high redox performance were retained and photocatalytic overall water splitting was realized. Driven by electrostatic force, the PDDA-functionalized BP nanosheets (F-BP) and layered BiOI were combined to form direct Z-scheme F-BP/BiOI nanohybrids (Fig. 10 a) [188]. The nanohybrids exhibited significant photocatalytic activity for degradation of both MB and TC under the irradiation of visible light. ESR and photocatalytic capture experiments proved that •O2 − and •OH are the main active species in the photocatalytic degradation process of F-BP/BiOI nanohybrids. According to the traditional type II charge transfer path, the photogenerated electrons accumulate on the CB of BiOI, which have not negative enough potential to reduce O2 to generate•O2 −. Similarly, the holes accumulated on the VB of cannot oxidize the OH to •OH. The results of ESR and active species capture experiments did not support the type II charge transfer path, and instead the Z-scheme charge transfer path is more rational for the F-BP/BiOI nanohybrids system (Fig. 10b). A 2D/2D BP/monolayer Bi2WO6 (BP/MBWO) direct Z-scheme heterojunction composed of BP nanosheets and monolayer Bi2WO6 was prepared, which showed excellent performance in photocatalytic NO removal and H2 production [184]. The TEM image demonstrated that there was a close contact between the monolayer Bi2WO6 and BP nanosheets in the BP/MBWO heterojunction (Fig. 10c). The ESR results showed that the •OH and •O2 − were the reactive oxygen species in this reaction system. Combining the results of ESR with the reduction potential required for photocatalytic NO reduction, the Z-scheme charge transfer mechanism between Bi2WO6 and BP was proposed (Fig. 10d), which met the minimum thermodynamic requirements for photoreduction of NO. Chen et al. constructed a BP-RP Z-scheme hetero-phase junction with high photocatalytic H2 production performance by an in-situ wet chemical method [186]. They traced the kinetics of the transfer of photogenerated electron-hole pairs in real time by time-resolved transient absorption spectroscopy, and judged the direct Z-scheme charge transfer mechanism between RP and BP as shown in the Fig. 10(e). Using a similar wet chemical method, they also reported that the RP-BP quantum dots Z-scheme structure also demonstrated excellent performance in photocatalytic water splitting [185]. The process of biocatalytic artificial photosynthesis (APS) is coupled with the photo-reduction process of NAD(P)H from NAD(P) + by photocatalysts and NAD(P)H-dependent redox enzymes to synthesize different chemical substances and CO2-based fuels, which has a wide range of application prospects. The development of Z-scheme biocatalytic artificial photosynthesis is even more exciting. Ji et al. reported a highly integrated AM and BP ultra-thin hybrid nanosheet (HNS) Z-scheme APS. The amphiphilic polymer functionalized with the electron mediator (M, [Cp*Rh(phen)Cl]Cl (Cp* =C5Me5, phen = 1,10-phenanthroline)) was used as a double-sided head to connect AM and BP through hydrophobic contact and electrostatic attraction, respectively (Fig. 10f), thereby constructing an AM/M/BP HNS-based Z-scheme system [189]. The Z-scheme was a direct Z-scheme structure in which the photogenerated electrons migrated in the direction of “BP-AM-M”(Fig. 10g). Compared with type I and type II heterojunctions, Z-scheme heterojunctions are more expected because of their more effective spatial separation of photogenerated carriers and strong redox capabilities. However, because of the same band structure as type II heterojunction, many characterization methods such as ESR, active species capture experiments, and time-resolved spectroscopy are often required to determine the Z-type charge transfer mechanism. 6.4 BP-based S-scheme heterojunction Yu's research group first proposed the concept of S-scheme system heterojunction in 2018 [202]. In their recent review, the charge transfer mechanism of S-scheme heterojunction was discussed in detail [203]. They believe that Z-scheme is a huge family, in which the concept of the original Z-Scheme comes from other fields with inherent defects, and subsequent generations of Z-Scheme will inevitably inherit the shortcomings of the original Z-Scheme. Therefore, they proposed the concept of S-scheme for the first time to describe the heterojunction photocatalytic system more accurately and vividly. As shown in the Fig. 11 (a), the semiconductor I (SC I) and the semiconductor II (SC II) have a staggered band gap configuration, wherein the SC II has a higher CB and VB position and a smaller work function. Such a difference will cause the electrons to spontaneously transfer from SC II to SC I when two semiconductors are in close contact, and an electron depletion layer and an electron accumulation layer are formed at the interface of SC I and SC II, respectively (Fig. 11b). Therefore, a built-in electric field from SC I to SC II will appear, which will accelerate the transfer of photogenerated electrons from SC I to SC II. Meanwhile, when SC I and SC II are in close contact, their Fermi levels will be pulled to the same level, causing the the Fermi levels of SC I and SC II to bend upward and downward, respectively (Fig. 11c), and finally promote the combination of meaningless photogenerated carriers at the contact interface. In brief, the built-in electric field, band bending, and Coulomb force work together to retain photogenerated electrons and holes with strong redox capabilities and participate in the photoredox system. In 2020, Li et al. reported the BP/BiOBr S-Scheme nano-heterojunction. They added BiOBr and BP to the NMP solution and prepared BP/BiOBr composites by ultrasound, and further processed the BP/BiOBr composites through solvothermal reaction and vacuum drying to obtain Sol-BP/BiOBr composites (Fig. 11d) [205]. The as-prepared Sol-BP/BiOBr demonstrate enhanced photodegradation performance of tetracycline (TC) and outstanding presentation of photocatalytic oxygen production. Through the analysis of the energy band structure of the two, they determined that BP belonged to the reducing oxidant with a small work function and a higher Fermi level, while BiOBr was an oxidizing reducing agent with a larger work function and a lower Fermi level (Fig. 11e). The difference in work function promoted the formation of a built-in electric field between BiOBr and BP, and the difference in Fermi energy level approved the bending of the energy bands of the two. Therefore, under the action of Coulomb force, the electrons in the CB of BiOBr migrated and recombined with the holes in the VB of BP, and then the photogenerated electrons with high reduction performance and the holes with high oxidation performance would be retained to form S-scheme photo-redox system. Zhang et al. anchored ultra-small Pt particles on the surface of BP nanosheets to act as promoters and protective reagents, and further used electrostatic self-assembly methods to combine Pt/BP and Bi2WO6 with oxygen vacancies (OvMBWO) to form S-scheme heterostructure of Pt/BP-OvMBWO, which showed excellent performance in the preparation of syngas by photocatalytic CO2 reduction [206]. The difference in work function between BP nanosheets and OvMBWO and the formation of p-n junction between the two promoted the formation of S-scheme charge transfer mechanism in Pt/BP-OvMBWO heterojunction (Fig. 11f). 6.5 BP/metal heterostructure Modification of semiconductor photocatalysts with metal particles is also an effective means to improve the performance of the photocatalysts. Due to the different work functions between the metal and the semiconductor, the Schottky barrier will be generated through the contact. The Schottky barrier can promote the transfer of photogenerated electrons from the semiconductor to the metal to improve the separation efficiency of photogenerated carriers [209]. Moreover, a large number of theoretical and experimental results have proved that the surface plasmon resonance (SPR) effect derived from the noble metal particles is of great benefit to the photocatalytic process [210–213]. SPR refers to that the metal particles generate free oscillations of internal electrons in response to specific incident photon energy to cause hot plasma electrons or enhanced local electromagnetic fields to promote the separation of photogenerated carriers at the metal–semiconductor interface. Bai et al. grew Pt metal particles on BP nanosheets by in-situ chemical reduction method to obtain a BP/Pt heterostructure, which displayed excellent performance in photocatalytic hydrogenation reactions [56]. The contact between the Pt and BP produced a Schottky barrier at the interface, which caused the band bending of BP and generated a built-in voltage to promote the migration of carriers from the BP to the Pt/BP interface (Fig. 12 a), and finally accumulated in the Pt. The ultra-fast transfer rate and accumulation of photogenerated electrons in the heterostructure made it excellent in electron-assisted photocatalytic hydrogenation reactions. The Pt/BP heterostructure completes 100% styrene hydrogenation within 25 minutes (Fig. 12b) and the turnover efficiency reached 5900 h−1 (Fig. 12c), which was much higher than other comparative samples. Furthermore, the PtP x O y composite formed by the combination of Pt and BP enhanced the stability of the heterostructure, and maintained efficient hydrogenation performance and stable structure after five cycles. Lei et al. used chemical reduction method to deposit Ag nanoparticles on few-layer BP nanosheets (fBP) and multilayer BP nanosheets (mBP) to obtain Ag/BP nanohybrid, and applied it to photocatalytic pollutant degradation [207]. It is calculated by density functional theory that the existence of covalent bonds between Ag nanoparticles and BP nanosheets and Ag-Ag interactions enable Ag nanoparticles to stably exist on the surface of BP nanosheets. The size of Ag particles is mainly around 40 nm (Fig. 12d), and the 5 wt% Ag/fBP shows the highest degradation rate in the degradation of RhB (Fig. 12e). The FDTD simulation calculated the spatial electric field distribution induced by the Ag nanoparticles LSPR in the hybrid (Fig. 12f). The calculation results showed that the thinning of the BP nanosheets and the increase in the size of Ag nanoparticles synergistically promoted the amplification of the local electric field, which was consistent with the highest photocatalytic performance of 5 wt% Ag/fBP. Due to its active synergistic coupling effect and the ability to stabilize free radicals, Au nanoparticles have been combined with 2D materials such as graphene and g-C3N4 in biomedical applications [214-216]. The broad light absorption range allows BP excellent photothermal effect and the production of active oxygen species under the irradiation of near-infrared light [217,218]. At the same time, BP also has good biocompatibility and biosafety [219,220]. These excellent properties make BP have great application prospects in the field of biomedicine. In view of the respective advantages of BP and Au nanoparticles, the Au/BP heterostructure (Fig. 12g) was prepared by Askoy et al., which was used for the antibacterial and anti-biofilm activity of the hospital pathogen fecal Escherichia coli [208]. In the antibacterial experiment, the bacteria treated with BP/Au nanocomposites under the irradiation of near-infrared light almost did not survive, and E. faecalis colony was not observed on the plate (Fig. 12h). The photothermal effect, nanoknife effect and oxidative pressure activity of the BP/Au nanocomposite contributed to its antibacterial effectiveness. In addition, this work also explored the anti-biofilm activity of the Au/BP nanocomposite, and the biofilm formation of Enterococcus faecalis was reduced by 58%. 6.6 BP/carbon-based material heterostructure Because of the unique physical and chemical properties, such as high carrier mobility, high light absorption, large specific surface area, low cost and environmental friendliness, graphene is widely used in the field of photocatalysis [221]. It is highly anticipated that graphene is coupled with BP to improve the photocatalytic performance of BP through the excellent physicalcochemical properties of the former. Ge et al. obtained a sandwich-structured rGO/BP/rGO by reducing and freeze-drying a mixture of BP nanosheets (BPNSs) and graphene [59]. During the freeze-drying process, the van der Waals contact between the reduced graphene sheets (rGO) and the sublimation of ice would cause the rGO to bend, thereby wrapping the two sides of the BPNSs to form a sandwich structure. The high-resolution TEM image of rGO/BP/rGO (Fig. 13 a) showed that the amorphous rGO layer tightly wrapped the well-crystallized sheet-like BPNSs, which prevented the BPNSs from contacting with the external environment and ensured the stability of the BPNSs. The π-π bond in the C1s XPS spectrum (Fig. 13b) in the heterostructure of rGO/BP/rGO indicated that there was a strong physical contact between rGO and BPNSs. The tight binding enabled the effective separation and transfer of photogenerated carriers between rGO and BPNSs, and the sandwich structure protected the BPNSs from oxidation, so the photocatalytic performance and stability of BPNSs were greatly improved. The reduced graphene enhanced the adsorption performance of the rGO/BP/rGO catalyst for MB, and the photocatalytic performance was also significantly enhanced (Fig. 13c). In addition, rGO/BP/rGO as a promising metal-free photocatalyst showed stable performance in three-cycle degradation. Zhang et al. constructed a BP-graphene hybrid through CVT, which exhibited significantly enhanced performance in the degradation of 2-chlorophenol (2-CP) [60]. XPS spectrum showed formation of a P-C bond in the hybrid, which makes the performance of the hybrid photocatalyst stable. In addition to graphene, C60 also has an application potential in the field of photocatalysis due to its excellent electron-accepting ability and high stability to light, oxygen and water [222,223]. Zhu et al. used an one-step chemical ball milling method to selectively bond C60 to the edge of the BP nanosheets (Fig. 13d) to construct an efficient and stable photocatalyst [223]. BP-C60 hybrid had significantly enhanced photoelectrochemical (Fig. 13e) and photocatalytic degradation performance. Fig. 13(f) was the energy band structure diagram of BP-BM and BP-C60 nanohybrid. Via the bonding of P-C, the photogenerated electrons were effectively transferred from BP to C60 to achieve carrier separation, thereby promoting the photoelectric conversion performance and photocatalytic activity of the hybrid. In addition, the effective bonding of C60 molecules on the edge of BP also protected the BP from oxidation, so the degradation rate of C60 modified BP nanosheets was inhibited by 4.6 times. By summarizing the heterostructure of graphene and C60 molecules combined with BP, it can be seen that the combination of carbon-based materials and BP promotes the spatial separation of photogenerated carriers through chemical bonding or physical bonding, and carbon-based materials can also protect BP from oxidization. It is expected to develop more types of carbon materials for compositing with BP, which can be applied for different photocatalytic reactions. 6.7 BP-based multicomponent heterojunction or heterostructure Multicomponent BP-based heterojunctions or heterostructures are generally ternary composites, such as BP-based ternary semiconductor heterojunctions, BP-graphene-semiconductor heterostructures, BP-semiconductor–metal heterostructures and BP-semiconductor-cocatalyst heterostructures, etc. Multi-component heterojunctions or heterostructures can take advantage of different materials, further optimize the carrier transport path, and enhance the absorption and utilization of solar energy. Zhang’s group combined La2Ti2O7 (LTO), CdS, and BP quantum dots (BPQDs) with near-infrared light response to prepare BP-CdS-LTO ternary heterojunction, which showed a H2 production efficiency of 0.96 mmol g-1h−1 under the full solar spectrum [224]. The band structure of the ternary heterojunction was shown in the Fig. 14 (a), and the stepped type II junction enabled the photogenerated carriers to be effectively separated. The authors detailedly explored the charger transfer dynamics in the ternary composite by femtosecond absorption spectroscopy (Fig. 14b). The results showed that the electrons in the ternary composite migrate from BPQDs to CdS and further migrate to LTO, and the electrons in CdS also injected into LTO, which proved the proposed mechanism. This work has important inspiration for the rational design of multi-nary junctional photocatalysts. Zhang’s research group has also reported a BP-Au-CdS ternary heterostructure composed of BPQDs, Au nanorods and CdS nanowires with excellent full-spectrum H2 production performance [225]. Au as an electronic intermediate formed a Schottky junction with CdS and matched the work function of BP, which enabled the effective separation of photogenerated carriers and a significant increase in carrier lifetime (Fig. 14c). Zhang et al. combined Mxene (Ti3C2T x ), TiO2 and BP nanosheets to prepare Ti3C2T x /TiO2–BP nanohybrids, which exhibited greatly enhanced the photodegradation performance for RhB and tetracycline hydrochloride (TCH) [226]. The result of theoretical calculation revealed the metallicity of Ti3C2T x , indicating that Ti3C2T x played the role of co-catalyst in the ternary heterostructure. Under the excitation of visible light, the electrons from the CB of BP were transferred to the CB of TiO2, and the difference between the Fermi level of TiO2 and Ti3C2T x formed a Schottky junction, which made the photogenerated electrons migrated from the TiO2 to Ti3C2T x (Fig. 14d). The excellent conductivity of Ti3C2T x enabled the photogenerated electrons to be migrated rapidly and generate active species with O2 molecules in the reaction system to participate in the photocatalytic reaction. In addition to improving the photocatalytic activity of photocatalysts, graphene can also be used as a surfactant to assist the liquid-phase exfoliation of bulk materials. Zhu et al. used graphene as both a surface modifier and a catalyst carrier to prepare MoS2-BP/GO photocatalyst [227]. Graphene oxide as a surface modifier prevented BP nanosheets from re-stacking during the exfoliation process and acted as a co-catalyst to modify MoS2. In the photocatalytic process, graphene acts as a catalyst carrier to promote the separation and transfer of carriers in the composite. In the ternary heterogeneous structure, graphene functioned as both a surface modifier and a catalyst carrier, becoming a bridge for connecting BP and MoS2 to achieve high-performance H2 production performance (Fig. 14e and f). 7 7 applications of BP-based heterostructured photocatalysts 7.1 Photocatalytic water splitting Hydrogen energy is considered to be the best alternative to fossil fuels due to its zero carbon emissions, high energy capacity and renewability [229–235], and the use of solar energy to split water molecules into O2 and H2 is the most ideal H2 production mode. Due to its adjustable band gap, wide spectral absorption range, and high hole mobility, BP has been widely used for photocatalytic water splitting in recent years. The redox potentials of photocatalytic O2 and H2 evolution are (1.23 V vs NHE for O2/H2O) and (0 V vs NHE for H+/H2), respectively (Fig. 15 a) [228]. Theoretical calculations showed that the band gap of BP can be adjusted so that it can easily meet the potential of H2 production, but it is difficult to reach the potential of O2 production. In addition, the instability of BP also limits its use as a single photocatalyst in photocatalytic water splitting. The Z-scheme BiVO4/BP heterojunction prepared by Majima’s group took full advantages of the band structures of BP and BiVO4 (Fig. 15b), and achieved overall water splitting in the visible light range [183]. Without adding any sacrificial reagents, the H2 and O2 production of BP/BiVO4 under visible light for 3 h reached 0.8 and 0.51 µmol, respectively (Fig. 15c). Under different LED monochromatic light, the composites also exhibit enhanced photocatalytic hydrogen production performance. In addition, Kong et.al anchored BP quantum dots to g-C3N4 (Fig. 15d), and achieved a significant increase in H2 production performance [176]. The photocatalytic H2 production efficiency of the optimal catalyst under simulated sunlight achieved 190 µmol h−1 (Fig. 15e), which was 3.45 times the H2 production performance of pure g-C3N4. Under different LED monochromatic light (LED-405, LED-420 and LED-505 nm), the heterojunction photocatalyst also displayed boosted photocatalytic H2 production performance. Li et al. combined BP nanosheets in different thicknesses with MoS2 by solvothermal method to construct a 2D/2D heterojunction (Fig. 15f) [43]. The experimental results showed that the combination of BP nanosheets obtained at high speed with MoS2 has a higher H2 production efficiency (1286 µmol h−1 g−1) than BP nanosheets obtained at low speed (398 µmol h−1 g−1) and bulk BP. This phenomenon was attributable to the fact that the BP nanosheets obtained at high rotation speed are thinner and the CB position is more negative, which provided sufficient driving force for photocatalytic H2 production. By comparing with the H2 production performance of the 0D/2D heterostructure, they also proved that the relatively large contact area of 2D/2D heterostructure provided more channels for photogenerated electron transfer (Fig. 15g), which led to more effective separation of photogenerated carriers and better photocatalytic performance (Fig. 15h). In comparison with other photocatalytic applications, the BP-based heterostructure is the most widely used for photocatalytic water splitting. The rational construction of BP-based heterostructure and the inherent advantages of BP allow the photogenerated carriers to be more effectively separated and participate in photocatalytic water splitting. Some typical BP-based heterostructures used in photocatalytic water splitting in Table 2 . 7.2 Photocatalytic CO2 reduction Excessive CO2 emissions will exacerbate global warming and cause a series of environmental and ecological problems. Using solar energy to drive semiconductor to convert CO2 into CO, CH4, CH3OH and other combustible gases can simultaneously solve energy and environmental problems caused by CO2 emissions [10,11,239–242].Therefore, it is of great significance to choose advanced semiconductors to stably and sustainably convert CO2 into other forms of carbon-containing energy. At present, some semiconductor materials such as TiO2 [243], CN [244], CsPb2Br3 [53], WO3 [192] and CTF [167] have been reported to form heterojunctions with BP for the reduction of CO2. Zhu et al. used a self-assembly method to anchor CsPbBr3 QDs on BP nanosheets to prepare a CsPbBr3/BP heterojunction with excellent CO2 reduction performance [53]. DFT theoretical calculation showed that Pb-P and Br-P covalent bonds were formed between CsPbBr3 and BP (Fig. 16 a). Further charge density difference analysis suggested that the existence of Pb-P covalent bonds (Fig. 16b) promoted the charge transfer at the interface between the two phases and the adsorption and activation of CO2. Due to the formation of Pb-P covalent bond and type I heterojunction in CsPbBr3/BP, the electrons were quickly transferred from CsPbBr3 to BP to reduce CO2, which resulted in the CH4 and CO production rate of 44.7 and 10.7 μmol g-1h−1, respectively (Fig. 16c). Zhang et al. combined 2D BP and 2D CTF to obtain a 2D/2D heterostructured BP-CTF photocatalyst [167]. The original CTF and BP tended to generate CO as the main product via two-electron CO2 photoreduction (Fig. 16d). Under visible light, the yield of CO produced by BP and CTF attained 1.6 and 2.40 μmol g-1h−1, respectively. While the yields of CO and CH4 of the BP-CTF composite photocatalyst were 4.53 and 7.68 μmol g−1h−1, respectively. Thus, BP-CTF exhibited not only enhanced CO2 reduction performance, but also produce value-added CH4 via the 8-electron reaction process (Fig. 16e). Theoretical calculation results revealed that the amalgamation of BP and CTF enhanced the bonding of the P atom and the intermediate product CO*, which facilitated the further hydrogenation of CO* to CH4. At the same time, the type I heterostructure accelerated the transfer of photogenerated carriers between CTF and BP, also promoting the photocatalytic CO2 reduction performance. The 0D-1D BP quantum dots -WO3 (BP QD-WO3) direct Z-scheme heterojunction composed of BP quantum dots and WO3 nanorods was applied to the reduction of CO2 [192]. BPQD-WO3 direct Z-scheme heterojunction had excellent CO2 reduction performance, and the obtained carbon-containing products included not only CO but also a certain amount of high value-added C2H4. Theoretical calculation results showed that the armchair and zigzag edges of BP (Fig. 16f) can promote the coupling of CO molecules and further transformation to C2H4 (Fig. 16g and h), indicating that BP played an important role in the selective production of carbon-containing fuels. In addition, the direct Z-scheme heterojunction allowed the catalyst carriers to be effectively separated while maintaining high redox capabilities, making it excellent in the photocatalytic CO2 reduction process. In short, BP-based heterojunction exhibits excellent photocatalytic CO2 reduction activity and high selectively for producing high value-added carbon-based fuels, which has great enlightening significance. However, there are relatively few reports on the BP-based heterostructures for photocatalytic CO2 reduction, so there is still plenty of room in this field. 7.3 Photocatalytic nitrogen fixation As an important industrial raw material, ammonia (NH3) has a great impact on human production and life and social development [245]. As the main raw material for NH3 preparation, N2 has a higher thermodynamic energy value of its N≡N bond, making it face great challenges for N2 reduction to produce NH3 [246]. The current industrial production of NH3 by the Haber − Bosch method requires harsh preparation conditions and huge energy consumption, and harms the ecological environment [247]. Therefore, it is extremely important to find a low-consumption and environmentally-friendly NH3 production method. Semiconductor photocatalytic N2 fixation is a process in which N≡N in N2 is activated by high-energy electrons and further converted into NH3 [248–251]. The whole process is environmentally friendly and harmless, which is an ideal NH3 production strategy. Chen's research group reported a metal-free photocatalyst (BPCNS) composed of BP nanosheets and carbon nitride nanosheets (CNS) with C-P bond for photocatalytic N2 fixation [49]. The N2 fixation rate of the optimal photocatalyst rate reached 347.5 µmol L-1h−1 (Fig. 17 a), which was 4 times that of CNS and even higher than that of Pt-supported CNS. The existence of the C-P bond played a vital role in the enhancement of the photocatalytic performance and stability of the composite. The C-P covalent bond in the composite can accelerate the transfer of charge carriers and improve the separation efficiency of photogenerated carriers. Additionally, compared with CNS, the CB of the composite is more negative, which is more conducive to the reduction of N2 (Fig. 17b). In terms of stability, the P-C bond occupied the lone pair of electrons on 0.05 BPCNS, which inhibited the oxidation of BP. Recently, Shen et al. reported that BP was used as a metal-free co-catalyst to modify CdS nanoparticles for efficient N2 fixation [170]. It was worth noting that the BP nanosheets (BPNSs) with good crystallinity and large area were obtained through electrochemical expansion method, avoiding the shortcomings of liquid-phase exfoliation, such as time-consuming, low yield and surface defects. BPNSs with a large area not only served as a good carrier for CdS nanoparticles (Fig. 17c), but also provided abundant active sites for photocatalytic reactions. Meanwhile, BP as a metal-free co-catalyst quickly transferred electrons from CdS to reduce N2 (Fig. 17d). Methanol added as a sacrificial reagent reacted with holes to generate abundant protons, which provides a hydrogen source to reduce N2 to NH3 while also suppressing water ionization.
