Finally, the maximum NH3 production of BPNS/CdS reached 57.64 μmol·L−1·h−1 (Fig. 17e). 7.4 Photocatalytic pollutant treatment The development of industrialization and the rapid increase of population have led to the release of more and more pollutants (including gas-phase pollutants, liquid organic pollutants heavy metal ions) into the environment, causing environment pollution and endangering human health. However, it is difficult to deal with these pollutants only by the self-repairing ability of nature. Semiconductor photocatalysis as a green and environmentally-friendly technology has been applied to air purification [252,253], degradation of dyes [254] and phenols [255], antibiotics [256] and the reduction of heavy metal ions [257,258]. In the process of photocatalytic pollutant treatment, holes, superoxide radicals and hydroxyl radicals as three main active species played a key role, which can oxidize pollutants into CO2 and H2O molecules. Wang et al. used a simple ultrasound-assisted method to load BP quantum dots onto 1D tubular g-C3N4 to obtain nano-hybrids (BPTCN) [49]. The photocatalyst displayed improved performance in the removal of chlortetracycline hydrochloride, tetracycline hydrochloride (Fig. 18 a) and RhB and the reduction of hexavalent chromium (Fig. 18b). The active species capture experiment and ESR characterization proved that the three active substances all play important roles in the degradation process (Fig. 18c). Nitrogen oxide (NO) is one of the main gases that cause photochemical smog and air pollution, which seriously affects people's daily activities and health. As mentioned in the previous section, the Bi2WO6/BP heterostructure with Z-scheme structure exhibited significantly enhanced NO removal performance [184]. The effective spatial charge separation of the Z-scheme structure promoted the generation of hydroxyl radicals and superoxide radicals, which were responsible for the excellent performance of Bi2WO6/BP. Besides, a ternary heterojunction (BP/PCN-HKUST-1) consisting of macroscopic photocatalytic membrane material combined with BP, porous g-C3N4 (PCN) and copper benzene tricarboxylate based metal organic frameworks (HKUST-1) was fabricated, which showed a NO removal ratio of 74% (Fig. 18d) [169]. The excellent adsorption capability of MOF materials enhanced the adsorption of NO, and the nested type I heterojunction (Fig. 18e) between BP and PCN allowed the effective separation of carriers and the production of active oxygen species, co-promoting the conversion of NO to NO3 –. 7.5 Photothermal and photodynamic therapy Cancer treatment is a medical problem faced by all mankind in the 21st century. The main clinical treatments for cancer so far, including surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, etc., have certain side effects, which will cause huge pain to cancer patients. In recent years, phototherapy, mainly photothermal and photodynamic therapy, has gradually been applied to tumor treatment [259,260]. Photothermal therapy uses a specific wavelength to excite a photothermal agent to generate heat to kill cancer cells, while photodynamic therapy essentially uses photocatalytic technology to induce a photosensitizer (photocatalyst) to produce abundant reactive oxygen species to destroy cancer cells [261]. Owing to the little damage to organs and tissues, good curative effect, few side effects and reduced suffering of patients, the above two methods are considered to show great development prospects. However, based on the penetrability of human tissues, photothermal and photodynamic therapy generally require near-infrared light as the radiation source, which requires the photothermal or photosensitizer to respond to near-infrared light. In addition, the biosafety of photothermal agents and photosensitizers needs to be considered as it is applied to biomedicine. The broad absorption range of BP from visible to near-infrared makes it an efficient photosensitizer [107]. The response to infrared light endows it with efficient photothermal effect, which can produce abundant active species. Phosphorus as an important element in the human body also ensures the biological safety of BP, including biocompatibility and biodegradability [217,219]. The above characteristics of BP make it an excellent candidate for photothermal and photodynamic therapy of cancer. High photothermal stability and rapid degradation are two very ideal properties of photothermal agents (PTA) in the clinical application of photothermal therapy (PTT). As a photothermal agent, BP has the biological safety of being easily degraded, but its photothermal stability is not satisfactory. Cu-based materials are also good photothermal candidates, and Cu ions and BP have inherent bonding properties. In view of the interaction between BP and Cu-based materials, Hu et al. combined BP and Cu2+ for cancer treatment [31]. Compared with the previous method of sacrificing the rapid degradation of BP to improve the photothermal stability, this smart strategy accelerated degradation while maintaining excellent photothermal stability. Under near-infrared laser irradiation, the tumor temperature in mice injected with RGD-conjugated polyethylene glycol (PEG) covering BP@Cu (BP@Cu@-PEG-RGD) nanostructured nanomaterials increased rapidly within 5 minutes by 30 °C to 56 °C (Fig. 19 a), and its photothermal performance is higher than other comparative samples and enough to achieve thermal ablation. In addition, the study used 64Cu2+, a common positron-emitting nuclide for nano-medicine tracing, to label BP to realize PET imaging and real-time monitoring of biodistribution and treatment effects in the body. PET imaging showed that the tumors in the mice treated with BP @Cu0.4@-PEG-RGD (Fig. 19b) were significantly smaller than the mice treated with saline (Fig. 19c). This method realized the good balance between the enhancement of the photothermal effect and the decomposition of the photothermal agent. The organelle-targeted phototherapy technology of nanomaterials can effectively select the lesion area to achieve precise treatment and is a minimally invasive treatment that can greatly reduce the pain of the patient [262,263]. In this context, Dong et.al developed an imaging-guided mitochondrial targeting photothermal/photodynamic nanosystem based on functionalized BP nanosheets [32]. BP nanosheets were first coated with polydopamine (PDA), and then covalently linked with chlorin e6 (Ce6) and triphenylphosphine (TPP), thus constructing BP@PDA-Ce6&TPP-NSs nanocomposite. In this nano-system, PDA formed a conformal layer on BP nanosheets, which can improve its light-to-heat conversion efficiency, provide amino anchor points for further functionalization, and enhance the stability of BP nanosheets. Ce6 had good reactive oxygen species generation ability and near-infrared fluorescence, which can be used for PDT and fluorescence imaging, and TPP provided mitochondrial targeting ability through membrane potential. Finally, in the 14-day treatment cycle, the tumors of the mice treated with the BP@PDA-Ce6&TPP-NSs nanocomposite under the irradiation of the laser were completely ablated (Fig. 19d). This work achieved real-time monitoring of photothermal and photodynamic combined therapy through in vivo fluorescence imaging, and gained excellent effects in inhibiting tumor growth. In addition to being used for photodynamic therapy of cancer, the photothermal effect of BP has also been well applied in the treatment of other diseases. Diabetic ulcers (DU) are a chronic complication of diabetes, usually in the form of chronic wounds (also called open ulcers) that appear on the feet and legs and other skin folds. The aggravation of wound infection will endorse the reproduction of bacteria and delay wound healing, and some patients have different degrees of pain problems [264,265]. In response to the above problems, Tao’s group developed a functionalized gel based on BP nanosheets with in-situ spraying, near-infrared response, analgesic and anti-inflammatory effects (Fig. 19e) [33]. This engineered BP-based gel used as an artificial “skin” after spraying, which not only temporarily protected the wound tissue from contact with the external environment, but also promoted endothelial cell proliferation and vascularization. At the same time, it was also used as a drug “repository”, and activated by near-infrared laser to generate local heat to accelerate blood flow in capillaries, trigger the release of lidocaine hydrochloride on demand to relieve pain, and eliminate bacteria and reduce inflammation through photothermal treatment. 8 BP-based heterostructrue for PEC water splitting PEC water splitting decomposes H2O molecules into H2 and O2 through photoelectric coupling, which is a green and environmentally-friendly way to obtain clean energy [267,268]. In the PEC system, one or two photoelectrodes (photocathode or photoanode) are used as working electrodes to capture the light to achieve water splitting. Therefore, the PEC system have three forms, single photoanode system, single photocathode system, dual-photoelectrode system (both photocathode and photoanode in one system) [266], as shown in the Fig. 20 . Taking the single photoanode system as an example, an n-type semiconductor is usually used as a photoanode, and a precious metal is used as a cathode (Fig. 20a). Under the light excitation, the photoanode produces the electron-hole pairs, and the electrons in the CB can be transported to the cathode wire through the external circuit to realize the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) of the two electrons, and the holes remain in the VB of the photoanode to participate in the four-electron oxygen evolution reaction (OER). In the PEC process of a single photocathode system (Fig. 20b), the HER occurs on the photocathode (usually a p-type semiconductor) and the OER occurs on the metal anode, which is the opposite of the PEC process of a single photoanode. The dual-photoelectrode system connects the two components in series through an external circuit (Fig. 20c). By selecting a suitable n-type semiconductor as photoanode and a p-type semiconductor as photocathode, it will generate an internal voltage that is sufficient for electrons to reach the photocathode, thereby achieving unbiased PEC water splitting. Compared with the photocathode and photoanode water splitting systems that require an external voltage, the advantages of the two-electrode system are more obvious. In addition, the HER on the photocathode and the OER on the photoanode need to meet the thermodynamic requirements, as shown by the following formulas (1) and (2). Photocathode: (1) 2 H + + 2 e - → H 2 E r e d u c t i o n 0 = 0 V Photoanode: (2) 2 H 2 O + 4 h + → O 2 + 4 H + E o x i d a t i o n 0 = + 1.23 V Therefore, it is necessary to select suitable semiconductor photoelectrodes to meet the thermodynamic requirements in the PEC process. Unlike the photocatalyst in the photocatalytic system, which mostly exists in the form of powder, the photoelectrode such as TiO2 [269–271], ZnO [272], Fe2O3 [273] and BiVO4 [274] in the PEC system is mostly attached to a certain substrate in the form of a thin film. In this context, BP can be combined with these semiconductors to form heterojunctions to enhance its photoelectric conversion performance. So far, BP was only combined with BiVO4 and TiO2 to be used in PEC water splitting system to the best of our knowledge, [61–64,275] which will be detailly discussed in the following. 8.1 BiVO4-BP heterojunction for PEC water splitting BiVO4 has a narrow band gap and a relatively positive VB position, which enable it to show considerable light absorption and water oxidation capabilities, so it is often used as a photoanode in the process of PEC water splitting [276,277]. However, the short hole transport distance and weak charge transport properties result in serious bulk and surface carriers recombination of BiVO4, which limits its PEC performance [278,279]. Zhang et al. reported that a few layers of BP can be used as a hole transport layer between BiVO4 and oxygen evolution co-catalyst (OEC) to achieve ultra-fast hole extraction [62]. The authors proved through theoretical calculations that BP had a greater influence on the electronic structure of BiVO4 (Fig. 21 a), causing its VB to bend upward. Combining theoretical calculations and experimental results, the possible band structure and built-in potential between BP and BiVO4 were proposed, as shown in Fig. 21(b). Furthermore, they proved through in-situ absorption spectroscopy that the external bias can accelerate the extraction of holes by BP. The OEC (NiOOH) was electrodeposited on the BiVO4/BP heterojunction, and the BP quickly transferred the holes in the BiVO4 to the NiOOH to complete rapid water oxidation. The final ternary composite NiOOH/BP/BiVO4 reached 4.48 mA cm−2 at 1.23 V vs RHE (Fig. 21c), and maintained stable performance during long-term performance testing. Lu et al. deposited MoS x on the BP/BiVO4 heterojunction by chemical vapor deposition method to construct a photoanode with excellent PEC performance and stability [61]. In this work, the authors also emphasized the important role of BP as a hole extraction layer. The final BiVO4/BP/MoS x obtained a photocurrent density of 2.1 mA cm−2 at 1.2 V vs Ag/AgCl (Fig. 21d), which was twice that of pure BiVO4, and only had a performance degradation of 0.8% in the nine-hour long-term stability test. As shown in the Fig. 21(e), the effective transfer path of photogenerated electron and holes in BiVO4/BP/MoS x in the PEC process gave rise to its excellent performance. Apart from to combining BP with BiVO4 as a photoanode, Wang et al. developed a BP/BiVO4 photocathode and constructed an unbiased tandem cell with a WO3-MOF photoanode (Fig. 21f) [275]. BiVO4/BP had an enhanced catalytic current and a more positive onset potential than BP photocathode under illumination (Fig. 21g). The Z-scheme heterostructure between BP and BiVO4 promoted the separation of carriers, so that the photogenerated electrons effectively reduced protons to H2. 8.2 TiO2-BP heterojunction for PEC water splitting Because of the favorable energy band position and excellent physical and chemical properties, the exploration of TiO2 as a photoanode has never stopped for decades [280,281]. But the wide intrinsic band gap and serious carrier recombination also lead to its poor PEC performance. In response to the above problems, Sun et al. introduced the oxygen vacancies and BP quantum dots (BP QDs) to synergistically improve the PEC performance of TiO2 nanotubes [64]. TiO2 nanotubes were obtained by electrochemical method on titanium foil, BP QDs were spin-coated on the TiO2 nanotubes, and then further processed by NaBH4 to obtain TiO2-x /BP photoanode (Fig. 22 a). As shown in the Fig. 22(b), the photocurrent increment (ΔI) of TiO2-x /BP photoanode at 1.23 V versus RHE is 0.74 mA cm−2, which is greater than the sum of the photocurrent increment of TiO2 sensitized only by BP QDs (ΔI = 0.29 mA cm−2) and TiO2 with only vacancies (ΔI = 0.27 mA cm−2). Through a series of characterizations, they concluded that the intervention of oxygen vacancies and the BP QDs promoted the separation and transport of carriers and increased the active area and reactive sites (Fig. 22c) to synergistically improve the PEC performance of TiO2. Zhang et al. also used spin coating to attach BP nanosheets with different concentrations to TiO2 nanorods [63]. The TEM image (Fig. 22d) of BP/TiO2 displayed that TiO2 nanorods and BP nanosheets had good heterogeneous interface contact. The composites with different amounts of BP nanosheets all showed improved PEC performance, and the optimal sample achieved 1.10 mA cm−2 at 1.23 V vs RHE (Fig. 22e). Through the analysis of the energy band structure of BP nanosheets and TiO2 nanorods, they proposed that the formation of type II heterojunction (Fig. 22f) between BP and TiO2 effectively promoted the separation of photogenerated carriers and ultimately leaded to excellent PEC performance. In general, the application of BP in PEC water splitting is less and the method of combining with photoanode is relatively simple, which leaves a lot of room for exploration of BP on PEC, and we hope that BP can be used in better and more in-depth applications on PEC. 9 Challenges and perspectives High carrier mobility, adjustable band gap, anisotropic structure and wide light absorption range allow BP to be a promising 2D material with important application prospects in the fields of optoelectronics and electronics. In this review, we summarized the crystal structure, band structure, anisotropy, and preparation of BP in different dimensions, and also give a comprehensive overview of the applications of BP-based heterostructures in photocatalysis and PEC water splitting, focusing on the principles of heterostructure design and the mechanism of photogenerated carrier separation. At the same time, the latest developments in the applications of BP heterostructures for photocatalytic water splitting, CO2 reduction, N2 fixation, pollutant treatment, photothermal and photodynamic therapy, and PEC water splitting applications were also sorted out. Since its first application in FET in 2014, BP has made considerable progress in many nano-scale applications. However, the application of BP is just the beginning in comparison with to other 2D materials that have been deeply applied, so the further in-depth application of BP is also facing a lot of opportunities and challenges, which are finely overviewed into the following four aspects. (1) After one hundred years of development, the most mature method for preparing bulk BP was based on the chemical vapor transport method developed by Thomas et al. in 2007. Although the cost of raw materials has been cut and the firing procedures have been simplified again and again, there are still drawbacks to this method. First, this method has high requirements for experimental conditions. At present, it can only be in the laboratory stage and cannot be prepared in large-scale batches. Second, this method requires the sealing of RP in the quartz tube and then high-temperature mineralization, which need high tube sealing technology and is likely to cause dangerous accidents. Therefore, the development of large-scale low-risk bulk BP preparation technology is an urgent problem to be solved. For the preparation of thin-layer BP, although more than a dozen preparation methods have been developed, the practical application still mainly depends on the top-down liquid phase exfoliation method. This method can obtain a large amount of thin-layer BP, but the as-prepared samples often have poor crystallinity and need to consume organic solvents. This increases the cost and is also not conducive to the application of environmentally-friendly photocatalysis or PEC processes. For these reasons, the development of more environmentally-friendly and practical methods of thin-layer BP is still a top priority. (2) The lone pair of electrons located in the 3 s orbital of BP can easily react with oxygen to form a P x O y group, which easily cause the oxidation and decomposition of BP and limits its application. At present, some methods for passivating BP are only limited to the laboratory stage and the process is cumbersome and expensive. The stability of BP-based heterostructures is generally improved due to heterogeneous contact or chemical bonding in photocatalytic applications, but the longer-term stability is still challenging. Therefore, more advanced and effective methods are needed to improve the stability of BP without affecting its intrinsic excellent characteristics. (3) Quite a bit of work have used various characterization methods, especially time-resolved spectroscopy, to explore the transfer path of photogenerated charge carriers of BP-based heterostructures in the process of photocatalytic and PEC processes, which is of great significance for exploring the catalytic reaction mechanism of heterostructures. However, it is more important to understand the surface process of the catalyst participating in the reaction in a deeper level. Therefore, using some in-situ characterization methods, such as Raman, Fourier infrared spectroscopy, XPS, etc., a deeper understanding of the mechanism of the BP-based heterostructure in the specific reaction process can be obtained. X-ray absorption near-edge structure spectrum can give the crystal structure information of the material and determine the adsorption site of the catalytic process. Moreover, the combination of theoretical calculations and aberration corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy can understand the changes in the catalytic process of BP-based materials on the atomic scale, and further explore its catalytic mechanism. (4) Apart from the construction of heterostructures, other modification strategies such as element doping, defect construction, crystal face control, and energy band engineering can also modify BP to regulate the separation of carriers and achieve high-performance catalytic reactions. BP has been well applied in the aspects of photocatalytic water decomposition and pollutant degradation, but it has hardly been applied in some emerging catalytic fields, for example, photocatalytic organic synthesis (oxidation of benzyl alcohol and urea). In these systems, the reaction solution may be an organic solvent, which may make BP more stable in the catalytic process. (5) At present, there are still not many reports on the applications of BP in the field of PEC reaction, and they mainly focuses on the application of PEC water splitting. Recently, layer-by-layer self-assembled BP was reported to be applied in PEC nitrogen fixation [282], which may inspire us that BP still has a lot of space for exploration in other application directions of PEC, such CO2 reduction, organic synthesis, etc. In fact, as a star 2D material in the post-graphene era, the application of BP in photocatalysis and PEC process is only a part of its application range. BP has also been widely developed and applied in batteries, FET, solar cells and gas sensors. More research enthusiasm and time should be devoted to the application and development of BP and its refined applications, making the BP more valuable. coredata.dc:description: Semiconductor-based photocatalytic and photoelectrochemical (PEC) processes can convert solar energy into high-density chemical energy or for the treatment of environmental pollutants, which are ideal ways to deal with environmental and energy crises. The development of high-efficiency photocatalysts and photoelectrodes is the key to the in-depth development and practical application of the two technologies. Black phosphorus (BP) has excellent physicalcochemical properties such as adjustable band gap, high carrier mobility, large specific surface area and anisotropy, making it one of the most promising catalysts. BP-based heterostructure can not only realize the effective separation of photogenerated carriers but also improve the stability of BP, and is widely used in photocatalytic and PEC reactions. In this review, we first introduce the crystal structure, band structure, anisotropy, and preparation of BP with different dimensions (bulk, zero-dimension and two-dimension). Then, according to the transfer path of the photogenerated carriers and the components, the BP-based heterostructures are divided into type I heterojunction, type II heterojunction, Z-scheme heterojunction, S-scheme heterojunction, BP/carbon-based material heterostructure, BP/metal heterostructure and multi-component heterostructure. Highlighted are the diverse photocatalytic applications of BP-based heterostructure, such as water splitting and CO2 reduction, N2 fixation, pollutant degradation, photothermal and photodynamic therapy. Finally, some concluding views and opinions are stated on the challenges and opportunities faced by the further development of BP-based heterostructures in photocatalysis and PEC water splitting.
